So the other thing too is you need to

root motion driven or if you're going to

sample is capsule driven, but the
animations themselves as examples are
also root motion built. So you can use
those for your project if you want
either or. And if you're unsure of the
difference between capsule driven versus
root motion, the capsule driven means
that whatever input happens goes onto
the capsule and then that pushes it
around and then the animation follows
that. Root motion driven means I move
the I push on the stick and there's some
parameters that uh check the animation
and then the animation decides how it's
going to move and that that gets pushed
to the capsule. So once it's feeling
good and you're you're feeling good

So let's talk about the blend stack. The

So, a blend stack node, what it does is
it's an animode that uh you plug in a
variable for the animation that you want
to play and all the other properties,
whether it's looping or uh play rate or
anything like that. I only use looping
here.
uh as an example, but anytime that
you're evaluating something inside of
your your event graph and you change
that animation property, what it will do
is it will take the animation that's in
that animation property and add it into
the stack to start a blend. So you can
imagine how this is powerful where
previously to do this in like a state
machine you'd have two conduits or two
states and then you would uh switch
between those and it would blend between
those two states and back and forth.
Here you can say okay this animation has
changed this variable's changed add to
the stack and start a blend. And you can
do the you can set a maximum number of
blends that can happen at a time as
well. So if you need to evaluate between
multiple animations pretty quickly, you
can just swap that variable information
out in your event graph, you're good to
go. And it has all the same blending
options that you could use uh hermetic
blends and things like that. And all the
options can be exposed so that you can
drive them via your event graph as you
need.
Okay, the next one is the chooser
player. So, same as a blend stack except
for instead of the animation variable
that you're choosing, you use a chooser
table. How many folks have used choosers
before?
Couple more. That's good. So, I don't go

a data. It's a table database that has
uh what assets you want to play and the
variables to decide what those assets
are going to be. And say for example you
have speeds and the table says okay well
at this speed I want to be running and
at this speed I want to play the the
walk animation. When you evaluate the
chooser table it's going to choose and
send out okay this is the animation I
should be playing right now. You can
also decide if you want to send out
multiple animations as well. So if
there's multiple options you can send
those out too. And that's how we can
motion match against mo multiple
animations if we like.

So the final piece of the puzzle to make

When you're dealing with a very sparse
anom set with a reduced lack of coverage
uh you're going to run into visual
issues and quite a few of them. And the
procedural nodes are here to help you uh
add that little bit of fidelity into
your motion uh to solve some of those
those fidelity problems. So uh there's
four key ones that I use in the sparse
extreme sparse example here. The first
one is offset root bone. Then the
steering node, the foot placement node,
and the meshbased additive stuff.
So, kind of going through each of these
nodes and how they function and why
they're important to this setup. We'll
start with the offset root bone. So,
this adds a tunable spring to your
motion. And the reason this is really
really important for uh your setup is
that oftentimes if you're capsule driven
and you're on say mouse and keyboard
where there's like not a lot of
acceleration or you have high
acceleration gameplay that's responsive.
As animators we kind of fight against
that because we want really nice motion
for example. So, what this does is it
allows you to have your capsule movement
be really tight and springy and really
responsive while also just giving you a
little bit of butter by taking the the
actor's root and moving it off of the
capsule and bringing it back slowly over
time on a spring. So, you can see it
here. This is the debug draw for this.
And there's it's there's kind of a bit
of noise in here, so I'm going to
explain it. The blue ring is the capsule
that movement that's happening. And the
green ring is the lag from the spring
applied from the offset root bone. And
there's a few properties associated with
it. You can do it accumulated.
There's a there's a drop down in there
to decide how you want that that lag to
to respond, but it's a super useful node
for creating just that, oh, I'm settling
in the motion. I'm coming out of a an
explosive thing, but not too fast. And
the other aspect that's really important
for this is the steering node. So
similar debug for this, but what the
steering node does is it modifies the
root motion to take your desired vector
which on say on a mouse and keyboard for

think about, is it handles like sloping
